speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about when you first started experiencing these new movements, and have you noticed any triggers that make them happen?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I started noticing these... movements about a month ago, I think. To be honest, I couldn't really pinpoint when they started, but I did notice that they seemed to get worse when I was stressed or anxious about school."

speaker: Doctor
text: "When did these movements start, and can you describe the type of movements you're experiencing? Are they involuntary or do they feel like something you're intentionally trying to do?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I guess it was around the same time I started feeling really overwhelmed with schoolwork and my coursework. The movements are more like... fidgeting, I suppose. I feel like I'm trying to do them, but they just seem to happen on their own."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'd like to take a closer look at your hands and arms, can you please extend them for me? And can you also tell me more about the duration of these movements, are they constant or do they come and go?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I can do that. I'll extend my arms for you. The movements seem to come and go, but they're more frequent when I'm sitting still for a long time. Sometimes I'll be in class or studying and I'll get caught up in my own thoughts and just fidget for hours without even realizing it."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Great, thank you for sharing that with me. Can you show me exactly what you mean by these movements, can you demonstrate them for me?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll try. *taps foot rapidly back and forth, then crosses and uncrosses legs multiple times* See, like that. I also do this a lot when I'm sitting still for a long time, like in class or when I'm watching TV."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities, do you find that these movements interfere with your work or daily tasks, and are there any situations that make them feel worse or better?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I try to avoid situations where I'm stuck in one place for too long, like in class or during long study sessions. But, I guess it's getting harder to avoid them now that they've become more noticeable. I'm worried that they might be affecting my focus and productivity."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities, do you find that these movements interfere with your work or daily tasks, and are there any situations that make them feel worse or better?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been trying to adjust my study schedule, taking more breaks and moving around more often. But it's still a struggle, especially when I'm trying to focus on a long assignment. I feel like I'm constantly on edge, worried that I'll start fidgeting again and lose my train of thought."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I see that the movements seem to be more pronounced when you're concentrating on something, is that correct? Can you tell me more about your concentration levels, do you find it difficult to focus on tasks?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I guess that's true. When I'm really focused on something, like studying for an exam or working on a project, I can feel myself getting more and more restless. It's like my brain just can't sit still for long."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns, do you find that these movements affect your ability to fall asleep or stay asleep at night?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I've been sleeping pretty well lately, which is kind of surprising considering how much I've been fidgeting. I think the risperidone I'm on has really helped with my sleep, to be honest. I usually go to bed around 10 or 11 PM and wake up around 6 or 7 AM, which seems normal for me."

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like you're having trouble articulating the movements. Can you try to describe them again, even if it feels awkward or uncomfortable? And just to clarify, when you say they're more pronounced when you're concentrating, do you mean that they feel like they're getting stronger or more frequent when you're focused on something?

speaker: Patient
text:
"I guess I'm just not used to talking about it. It feels a bit silly, to be honest. The movements are like... my body just can't seem to stop itself from moving, even when I'm trying to relax or focus."

"Yes, I mean that they feel like they're getting stronger or more frequent when I'm trying to concentrate on something. It's like my brain and body are working against each other, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you try to describe these movements again, and this time, please focus on the sensation or feeling you experience while they're happening? For example, do you feel like your muscles are trembling, or is there a sense of stiffness?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's like... I feel like my body is just on high alert, like I'm waiting for something to happen. My muscles feel tense, like they're coiled and ready to spring into action at any moment. It's a weird, unsettling feeling that's hard to describe."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I appreciate your effort to describe the sensations, can you try to pinpoint exactly when you first noticed this feeling, was it immediately after the movements started or did it come later? And can you also tell me more about your emotional state, have you noticed any mood swings or feelings of anxiety since the movements began?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I think it started to feel like this around the same time I started feeling really overwhelmed with schoolwork and my coursework. It's like my body just became more hyper-vigilant, always on the lookout for something to react to. I've also noticed that when I'm feeling anxious or stressed, my heart starts racing and I can feel my palms getting sweaty, which is really uncomfortable."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, I'm going to take a closer look at your face and head, can you please follow my gaze upwards?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'm looking up now. What are you looking for?"

speaker: Doctor
text: "Great, thank you for following my gaze. Can you please look upwards and tell me if you notice anything unusual in your vision or the way your eyes move?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I don't really notice anything out of the ordinary. My eyes feel fine, and I don't see anything weird in my vision. But I do get these... weird feelings in my head sometimes, like there's something buzzing or vibrating, but I don't know what it is."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your emotional state, have you noticed any mood swings or feelings of anxiety since the movements began?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've noticed that when I'm feeling really anxious or stressed, my mind starts racing and I get these... thoughts that feel really disjointed and hard to follow. It's like my brain is jumping from one thing to another without making any sense. And sometimes, I'll get these... feelings of being 'on edge' that make me feel like I'm waiting for something to happen, even when there's nothing to wait for."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about any changes you've noticed in your vision, such as double vision, blurry vision, or sensitivity to light?



Also, REQUEST TEST: EMG (Electromyogram)

speaker: Measurement
text:
VISION: NORMAL READINGS

EMG (Electromyogram): Abnormal Readings: Muscle activity is elevated, indicating increased muscle tension.

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about your family medical history, have any of your relatives been diagnosed with neurological disorders such as Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, or dystonia?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, my family hasn't really been diagnosed with anything like that. My parents are both pretty healthy, and my grandparents are mostly fine too. I do have an older brother who's been dealing with some anxiety issues, but I don't think that's directly related to me."

speaker: Doctor
text:

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your family medical history, specifically any relatives who have been diagnosed with neurological disorders?

speaker: Patient
text: "My parents are pretty healthy, and my grandparents are mostly fine too. I do have an older brother who's been dealing with some anxiety issues, but I don't think that's directly related to me."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about your family medical history, specifically any relatives who have been diagnosed with neurological disorders? 

Also, have you noticed any other symptoms such as tremors, weakness, or difficulty with speech or swallowing?

speaker: Patient
text: "My parents are pretty healthy, and my grandparents are mostly fine too. I do have an older brother who's been dealing with some anxiety issues, but I don't think that's directly related to me. As for other symptoms, I don't really notice any tremors, but I do feel like my hands can be a bit unsteady when I'm trying to write or draw. And when I'm speaking, I sometimes feel like my words get a bit jumbled or hard to follow, but I don't think it's because of anything I'm doing, just that my brain feels like it's racing."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for sharing all the information with me. Based on our conversation, I'm going to need to review the test results before making a diagnosis. Can you please wait for just a few minutes while I review the EMG and Blood Lipid Profile results?"
